dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Welcome back, everyone. Today, we've got a wild story about ambition, uh, and maybe a little bit of a white elephant situation in Spain.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Welcome back, everyone. Today, we've got a wild story about ambition, uh, and maybe a little bit of a white elephant situation in Spain.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, it's a fascinating look at infrastructure projects, especially in the early 2000s when the European economy was, like, pretty stagnant, you know? Lots of debt.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, it's a fascinating look at infrastructure projects, especially in the early two thousand seconds when the European economy was, like, pretty stagnant, you know? Lots of debt.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The European economy was booming, fuelled by debt in the early 2000s.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Right, especially southern Europe, dealing with recessions, construction projects getting cancelled left and right.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right, especially southern Europe, dealing with recessions, construction projects getting cancelled left and right.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Southern Europe was on a resurgent growth path which meant construction projects were easily funded to cater to this expansion.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: But then, suddenly, there's this financial boom! Demand for travel, for infrastructure. And that’s where our story really kicks off, with Ciudad Real airport.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: But then, suddenly, there's this financial boom! Demand for travel, for infrastructure. And that's where our story really kicks off, with Ciudad Real airport.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The European economy was booming, fuelled by debt in the early 2000s. ... Then, the financial crisis hit. Demand waned, for both travel and infrastructure investment, leaving some grandiose construction projects abandoned.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Ah, yes. Ciudad Real. So, this was initially pitched as, what, an alternative to Madrid’s main Barajas airport? Even though it was, like, a fair distance away?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Ah, yes. Ciudad Real. So, this was initially pitched as, what, an alternative to Madrid's main Barajas airport? Even though it was, like, a fair distance away?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Originally designed to take excess traffic away from Madrid Barajas airport, the airfield was located a staggering 150 miles North of the city.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly! And for a while, it actually, um, seemed to work. High-cost airlines were thriving, and Ciudad Real’s central location made it popular for passengers and airlines. Ryanair, Vueling, they were flying in.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly! And for a while, it actually, um, seemed to work. High-cost airlines were thriving, and Ciudad Real's central location made it popular for passengers and airlines. Ryanair, Vueling, they were flying in.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: At a time when low-cost airlines were keeping costs down by serving secondary airports, the remote location of Ciudad Real seemed a little too much for passengers and airlines alike to absorb.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: So, it was open for five years, making profits, in pristine condition, and then... [interrupts] what was that weird detail about painting crosses on the runway?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So, it was open for five years, making profits, in pristine condition, and then... what was that weird detail about painting crosses on the runway?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The international airport was open for just three years and saw flights from only two airlinesRyanair and Vueling, with the latter having its flights subsidised by the government.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Oh, yeah! They actually had to paint large green crosses over the pristine runways just so pilots knew the airfield was operational because it was so empty!
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh, yeah! They actually had to paint large green crosses over the pristine runways just so pilots knew the airfield was operational because it was so empty!
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: ...having to paint large yellow crosses over the crumbling runway so pilots knew the airfield was abandoned...

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: That's just... so symbolic, isn't it? Like, "Yes, we're open, just ignore the giant X's." So, then what happened? The bottom fell out?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: That's just... so symbolic, isn't it? Like, Yes, we're open, just ignore the giant X's. So, then what happened? The bottom fell out?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Pretty much. It was never put up for sale initially, but eventually, it sold in 2015 for, get this, 10 million Euros. After an initial price tag of 80 million.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Pretty much. It was never put up for sale initially, but eventually, it sold in twenty fifteen for, get this, ten million Euros. After an initial price tag of eighty million.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: ...that airport was eventually picked up in July 2015 by Tzaneen International, a group of British and Asian investors, for just 10,000.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Wait, from 80 million to 10 million? That's, like, an 87% loss! Who bought it for that little?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Wait, from eighty million to ten million? That's, like, an eighty seven percent loss! Who bought it for that little?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: A consortium of local and Chinese investors. And they immediately announced plans to downsize operations, just maintenance and flight training.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: A consortium of local and Chinese investors. And they immediately announced plans to downsize operations, just maintenance and flight training.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The firm said in a statement that it planned to invest between 60 to 100 million into regenerating the airfield on the basis that several Chinese companies are interested in making it into their main point of entry into Europe.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Okay, so not exactly the bustling international hub it was meant to be. And then there was that other crazy bid, right? For just a parking lot?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Okay, so not exactly the bustling international hub it was meant to be. And then there was that other crazy bid, right? For just a parking lot?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Uh-huh. Later that same year, an unidentified investor proposed 28 million for just a parking lot near the airfield. That, thankfully, didn't go through.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Uh-huh. Later that same year, an unidentified investor proposed twenty eight million for just a parking lot near the airfield. That, thankfully, didn't go through.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Later that year, an unidentified investor proposed a 28 million bid for the airfield to the courts, however, that potential transaction also fell through.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: "Thankfully"? I mean, 28 million for a parking lot at a 10-million-euro airport, that would have been wild!
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Thankfully? I mean, twenty eight million for a parking lot at a ten-million-euro airport, that would have been wild!

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: It would! But then, in 2018, it sold *again* for 56.2 million.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It would! But then, in twenty eighteen, it sold again for fifty six point two million.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Three years later the airport was eventually sold for 56.2 million to Ciudad Real International Airport SL in September 2018...

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: So, it went up in value after being a ghost airport? And it had a "last flight" with, ironically, a full 747?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So, it went up in value after being a ghost airport? And it had a last flight with, ironically, a full seven hundred forty seven?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: ...the previously abandoned airport received its first flight last monthironically with no passengers on. A 747 landed at the airstrip.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Yep. Now it’s trying to rebrand as "Madrid Airport South," focusing on cargo, maintenance, and flight training. No commercial traffic.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yep. Now it's trying to rebrand as Madrid Airport South, focusing on cargo, maintenance, and flight training. No commercial traffic.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: ...an attempt to rebrand the airfield as Madrid Airport South being halted... who have left their doors open for commercial traffic along with the alternative aviation activities they have proposed...

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: But with another new airport opening near Madrid, Casarrubios del Monte, does Madrid even *need* another passenger airport? And will people really transit that far for a short-haul flight?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: But with another new airport opening near Madrid, Casarrubios del Monte, does Madrid even need another passenger airport? And will people really transit that far for a short-haul flight?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Unfortunately, though, there is the increasing prospect of Madrid getting a brand new second airport, just over 20 miles from the city in Casarrubios del Monte. This facility could even see construction begin in 2020 if it gets approval and largely caters to the low-cost market for Madrid.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: That's the million-dollar question, um, or really, the multi-million dollar question. It seems like it'll be a long time before we see passenger departures from Ciudad Real again, if ever.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: That's the million-dollar question, um, or really, the multi-million dollar question. It seems like it'll be a long time before we see passenger departures from Ciudad Real again, if ever.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: What a story of, like, misplaced ambition and the harsh realities of economics, you know?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: What a story of, like, misplaced ambition and the harsh realities of economics, you know?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: It really is. A true "airport to nowhere" saga, trying to find its purpose.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It really is. A true airport to nowhere saga, trying to find its purpose.
